member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMembersAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that certain members on a specified are accessed dynamically, for example through .
member.remarks:
This allows tools to understand which members are being accessed during the execution of a program.
This attribute is valid on members whose type is or .
When this attribute is applied to a location of type , the assumption is that the string represents a fully qualified type name.
When this attribute is applied to a class, interface, or struct, the members specified can be accessed dynamically on instances returned from calling on instances of that class, interface, or struct.
If the attribute is applied to a method it's treated as a special case and it implies the attribute should be applied to the "this" parameter of the method. As such the attribute should only be used on instance methods of types assignable to System.Type (or string, but no methods will use it there).

member.name: F:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.DefaultInterpolatedStringHandler.GuessedLengthPerHole
member.summary: Expected average length of formatted data used for an individual interpolation expression result.
member.remarks: This is inherited from string.Format, and could be changed based on further data. string.Format actually uses `format.Length + args.Length * 8`, but format.Length includes the format items themselves, e.g. "{0}", and since it's rare to have double-digit numbers of items, we bump the 8 up to 11 to account for the three extra characters in "{d}", since the compiler-provided base length won't include the equivalent character count.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.DefaultInterpolatedStringHandler._hasCustomFormatter
member.summary: Whether provides an ICustomFormatter.
member.remarks: Custom formatters are very rare. We want to support them, but it's ok if we make them more expensive in order to make them as pay-for-play as possible. So, we avoid adding another reference type field to reduce the size of the handler and to reduce required zero'ing, by only storing whether the provider provides a formatter, rather than actually storing the formatter. This in turn means, if there is a formatter, we pay for the extra interface call on each AppendFormatted that needs it.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.DisableRuntimeMarshallingAttribute
member.summary: Disables the built-in runtime managed/unmanaged marshalling subsystem for P/Invokes, Delegate types, and unmanaged function pointer invocations.
member.remarks:
Note: This does nothing on runtimes older than .NET 7. It is provided entirely for forward compatibility. The built-in marshalling subsystem has some behaviors that cannot be changed due to backward-compatibility requirements. This attribute allows disabling the built-in subsystem and instead uses the following rules for P/Invokes, Delegates, and unmanaged function pointer invocations:
- All value types that do not contain reference type fields recursively (unmanaged in C#) are blittable - Value types that recursively have any fields that have [StructLayout(LayoutKind.Auto)] are disallowed from interop. - All reference types are disallowed from usage in interop scenarios. - SetLastError support in P/Invokes is disabled. - varargs support is disabled. - LCIDConversionAttribute support is disabled.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.ModuleInitializerAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate to the compiler that a method should be called in its containing module's initializer.
member.remarks:
When one or more valid methods with this attribute are found in a compilation, the compiler will emit a module initializer which calls each of the attributed methods.
Certain requirements are imposed on any method targeted with this attribute: - The method must be `static`. - The method must be an ordinary member method, as opposed to a property accessor, constructor, local function, etc. - The method must be parameterless. - The method must return `void`. - The method must not be generic or be contained in a generic type. - The method's effective accessibility must be `internal` or `public`.
The specification for module initializers in the .NET runtime can be found here: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/design/specs/Ecma-335-Augments.md#module-initializer

member.name: T:System.Buffers.ArrayPool`1
member.summary: Provides a resource pool that enables reusing instances of arrays.

remarks.para: Renting and returning buffers with an can increase performance in situations where arrays are created and destroyed frequently, resulting in significant memory pressure on the garbage collector.
This class is thread-safe. All members may be used by multiple threads concurrently.

member.name: P:System.Buffers.ArrayPool`1.Shared
member.summary: Retrieves a shared instance.
member.remarks: The shared pool provides a default implementation of that's intended for general applicability. It maintains arrays of multiple sizes, and may hand back a larger array than was actually requested, but will never hand back a smaller array than was requested. Renting a buffer from it with will result in an existing buffer being taken from the pool if an appropriate buffer is available or in a new buffer being allocated if one is not available. byte[] and char[] are the most commonly pooled array types. For these we use a special pool type optimized for very fast access speeds, at the expense of more memory consumption. The shared pool instance is created lazily on first access.

member.name: M:System.Buffers.ArrayPool`1.Create
member.summary: Creates a new instance using default configuration options.

member.name: M:System.Buffers.ArrayPool`1.Create(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new instance using custom configuration options.
member.param: The maximum length of array instances that may be stored in the pool.
The maximum number of array instances that may be stored in each bucket in the pool. The pool groups arrays of similar lengths into buckets for faster access.
member.returns: A new instance with the specified configuration options.
member.remarks: The created pool will group arrays into buckets, with no more than in each bucket and with those arrays not exceeding in length.

member.name: M:System.Buffers.ArrayPool`1.Rent(System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves a buffer that is at least the requested length.
member.param: The minimum length of the array needed.
member.returns: An array that is at least in length.
member.remarks: This buffer is loaned to the caller and should be returned to the same pool via so that it may be reused in subsequent usage of . It is not a fatal error to not return a rented buffer, but failure to do so may lead to decreased application performance, as the pool may need to create a new buffer to replace the one lost.

member.name: M:System.Buffers.ArrayPool`1.Return(`0[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns to the pool an array that was previously obtained via on the same instance.
member.param: The buffer previously obtained from to return to the pool.

If true and if the pool will store the buffer to enable subsequent reuse, will clear of its contents so that a subsequent consumer via will not see the previous consumer's content. If false or if the pool will release the buffer, the array's contents are left unchanged.
member.remarks: Once a buffer has been returned to the pool, the caller gives up all ownership of the buffer and must not use it. The reference returned from a given call to must only be returned via once. The default may hold onto the returned buffer in order to rent it again, or it may release the returned buffer if it's determined that the pool already has enough buffers stored.

member.name: T:System.Buffers.TlsOverPerCoreLockedStacksArrayPool`1
member.summary: Provides an ArrayPool implementation meant to be used as the singleton returned from ArrayPool.Shared.
member.remarks: The implementation uses a tiered caching scheme, with a small per-thread cache for each array size, followed by a cache per array size shared by all threads, split into per-core stacks meant to be used by threads running on that core. Locks are used to protect each per-core stack, because a thread can migrate after checking its processor number, because multiple threads could interleave on the same core, and because a thread is allowed to check other core's buckets if its core's bucket is empty/full.

member.name: F:System.Buffers.TlsOverPerCoreLockedStacksArrayPool`1.NumBuckets
member.summary: The number of buckets (array sizes) in the pool, one for each array length, starting from length 16.

member.summary: Maximum number of per-core stacks to use per array size.

member.name: F:System.Buffers.TlsOverPerCoreLockedStacksArrayPool`1.MaxBuffersPerArraySizePerCore
member.summary: The maximum number of buffers to store in a bucket's global queue.

member.name: F:System.Buffers.TlsOverPerCoreLockedStacksArrayPool`1.t_tlsBuckets
member.summary: A per-thread array of arrays, to cache one array per array size per thread.

member.summary: Used to keep track of all thread local buckets for trimming if needed.

member.name: F:System.Buffers.TlsOverPerCoreLockedStacksArrayPool`1._buckets
member.summary: An array of per-core array stacks. The slots are lazily initialized to avoid creating lots of overhead for unused array sizes.

member.name: M:System.SpanHelpers.CopyTo``1(``0@,System.Int32,``0@,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Implements the copy functionality used by Span and ReadOnlySpan.
NOTE: Fast span implements TryCopyTo in corelib and therefore this implementation is only used by portable span. The code must live in code that only compiles for portable span which means either each individual span implementation of this shared code file. Other shared SpanHelper.X.cs files are compiled for both portable and fast span implementations.

member.name: M:System.SpanHelpers.Add``1(System.IntPtr,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Computes "start + index * sizeof(T)", using the unsigned IntPtr-sized multiplication for 32 and 64 bits.
Assumptions: Start and index are non-negative, and already pre-validated to be within the valid range of their containing Span.
If the byte length (Span.Length * sizeof(T)) does an unsigned overflow (i.e. the buffer wraps or is too big to fit within the address space), the behavior is undefined.

member.name: M:System.SpanHelpers.IsReferenceOrContainsReferences``1
member.summary: Determine if a type is eligible for storage in unmanaged memory. Portable equivalent of RuntimeHelpers.IsReferenceOrContainsReferences{T}()
